column2: after an adversary hearing
column3: that no release conditions ""will reasonably assure . . . the safety of any other person and the community.""  18 U.S.C.  3142(e) (1982 ed.
column4: Supp. III).  The Act provides arrestees with a number of procedural rights at the detention hearing
column5: including the right to request counsel
column6: to testify
column7: to present witnesses
column8: to proffer evidence
column9: and to cross-examine other witnesses.  The Act also specifies the factors to be considered in making the detention decision
column10: including the nature and seriousness of the charges
column11: the substantiality of the Government's evidence
column13: and the nature and seriousness of the danger posed by his release.  Under the Act
column14: a decision to detain must be supported by written findings of fact and a statement of reasons
column15: and is immediately reviewable.  After a hearing under the Act
column16: the District Court ordered the detention of respondents
column17: who had been charged with 35 acts of racketeering activity.  The Court of Appeals reversed
column18: holding that  3142(e)'s authorization of pretrial detention on the ground of future dangerousness is facially unconstitutional as violative of the Fifth Amendment's substantive due process guarantee.

column1: 1. Given the Act's legitimate and compelling regulatory purpose and the procedural protections it offers
column2: 3142(e) is not facially invalid under the Due Process Clause.  Pp.  481 U. S. 746-752.

column1: (a) The argument that the Act violates substantive due process because the detention it authorizes constitutes impermissible punishment before trial is unpersuasive.  The Act's legislative history clearly indicates that Congress formulated the detention provisions not as punishment for dangerous individuals
column2: but as a potential solution to the pressing societal problem of crimes committed by persons on release.  Preventing danger to the community is a legitimate regulatory goal.  Moreover
column3: the incidents of detention under the Act are not excessive in relation to that goal
column4: since the Act carefully limits the circumstances under which detention may be sought to the most serious of crimes
column5: the arrestee is entitled to a prompt hearing
column6: the maximum length of detention

column1: is limited by the Speedy Trial Act
column2: and detainees must be housed apart from convicts.  Thus
column3: the Act constitutes permissible regulation
column4: rather than impermissible punishment.  Pp.  481 U. S. 746-748.

column1: (b) The Court of Appeals erred in ruling that the Due Process Clause categorically prohibits pretrial detention that is imposed as a regulatory measure on the ground of community danger.  The Government's regulatory interest in community safety can
column2: in appropriate circumstances
column3: outweigh an individual's liberty interest.  Such circumstances exist here.  The Act narrowly focuses on a particularly acute problem -- crime by arrestees -- in which the Government's interests are overwhelming.  Moreover
column4: the Act operates only on individuals who have been arrested for particular extremely serious offenses
column5: and carefully delineates the circumstances under which detention will be permitted.  Pp.  481 U. S. 748-751.

column1: (c) The Act's extensive procedural safeguards are specifically designed to further the accuracy of the likelihood-of-future-dangerousness determination
column2: and are sufficient to withstand respondents' facial challenge
column3: since they are more than ""adequate to authorize the pretrial detention of at least some [persons] charged with crimes.""  Schall v. Martin

column1: 2. Section 3142(e) is not facially unconstitutional as violative of the Excessive Bail Clause of the Eighth Amendment.  The contention that the Act violates the Clause because it allows courts essentially to set bail at an infinite amount for reasons not related to the risk of flight is not persuasive.  Nothing in the Clause's text limits the Government's interest in the setting of bail solely to the prevention of flight.  Where Congress has mandated detention on the basis of some other compelling interest -- here
column2: the public safety -- the Eighth Amendment does not require release on bail.  Pp.  481 U. S. 752-755.
reversed.

column1: Federal Rule of Appellate Procedure 23(c) provides that
column2: when a State appeals a federal court decision granting a writ of habeas corpus to a state prisoner
column3: the habeas petitioner shall be released from custody ""unless the court or justice or judge rendering the decision
column4: or the court of appeals or the Supreme Court
column5: or a judge or justice of either court shall otherwise order.""  Rule 23(d) states that initial orders issued pursuant to Rule 23(c) shall

column1: govern review in the court of appeals and in the Supreme Court unless for special reasons shown . . . the order shall be modified
column2: or an independent order respecting custody
column3: enlargement or surety shall be made.""

column2: a prisoner serving a state court sentence
column3: filed a habeas corpus petition in the Federal District Court
column4: which found that his constitutional rights had been violated at his state court trial and ordered that a writ of habeas corpus ""shall issue unless within 30 days"" the State granted a new trial.  The court subsequently denied petitioners' motion to stay its order pending appeal
column5: basing its denial on Third Circuit authority that
column6: under Rules 23(c) and (d)
column7: a federal court deciding whether to release a successful habeas petitioner could consider only the risk that the prisoner would not appear for subsequent proceedings
column8: not his danger to the community
column9: and finding that petitioners had failed to show such risk here. The Court of Appeals denied petitioners' motion for a stay of the District Court's order releasing respondent.

column1: Held:  In deciding under Rules 23(c) and (d) whether to stay pending appeal a district court order granting relief to a habeas petitioner
column2: federal courts are not restricted to considering only the petitioner's risk of flight.  The history of federal habeas corpus practice indicates that a court has broad discretion in conditioning a judgment granting habeas relief
column3: and a court's denial of enlargement to a successful habeas petitioner pending review of the habeas order has the same effect as a stay of that order.  Since habeas corpus proceedings are civil in nature
column4: federal courts
column5: in deciding under the Rule whether to release a successful habeas petitioner pending the State's appeal
column6: should be guided by the traditional standards governing stays of civil judgments -- whether the stay applicant has made a strong showing that he is likely to succeed on the merits;

column1: whether the applicant will be irreparably injured absent a stay; whether issuance of the stay will substantially injure the other parties interested in the proceeding; and where the public interest lies.  Although Rule 23(c) creates a presumption favoring release of a successful habeas petitioner pending appeal
column2: and Rule 23(d) creates a presumption of correctness of the District Court's order
column3: such presumptions may be overcome if so indicated by the traditional stay factors
column4: which contemplate individualized judgments in each case.  Thus
column5: consideration may be given to such factors as the possibility of the prisoner's flight; the risk that the prisoner will pose a danger to the public if released; the State's interest in continuing custody and rehabilitation pending a final determination on appeal; and the prisoner's substantial interest in release pending appeal.  Respondent's contention that matters of ""traditional state concern"" such as the prisoner's danger to the community should not be considered in determining whether to release the prisoner pending appeal is unpersuasive.  Any strain on federal-state relations that arises from federal habeas jurisdiction comes about because of the granting of habeas relief itself
column6: not the existence of habeas courts' discretion to refuse enlargement of a successful habeas petitioner pending appeal.  Nor is there any merit to respondent's contention that staying a successful habeas petitioner's release pending appeal because of dangerousness is repugnant to the concept of substantive due process.  Pp.  481 U. S. 774-779.

In an agreement settling a suit in which they had been named as defendants
column2: two of the petitioners consented to the entry of a permanent injunction prohibiting them from infringing the trademark of respondent leather goods manufacturer (hereinafter respondent).  Subsequently
column3: upon submission of an affidavit by respondent's attorneys
column4: the District Court found probable cause to believe that petitioners were engaged in conduct violative of the injunction.  The court therefore granted the request of respondent's attorneys for appointment as special counsel to represent the Government in the investigation and prosecution of a criminal contempt action against petitioners.  Ultimately
column5: a jury convicted petitioners of either criminal contempt or of aiding and abetting that contempt.  The Court of Appeals affirmed
column6: rejecting petitioners' contention that the appointment of respondent's attorneys as special counsel violated their right to be prosecuted by an impartial prosecutor.  The court stated
column7: inter alia
column8: that the judge's supervision of a contempt prosecution is generally sufficient to prevent the danger that the special prosecutor will use the threat of prosecution as a bargaining chip in civil negotiations.

column2: reversed.

column1: JUSTICE BRENNAN delivered the opinion of the Court as to Parts I
column2: II
column3: III-A
column4: and IV
column5: concluding that:

column1: 1. District courts have authority to appoint private attorneys to prosecute criminal contempt actions.  Pp.  481 U. S. 793-802.
(a) Although Federal Rule of Criminal Procedure 42(b) does not authorize the appointment of private attorneys
column2: its reference to such appointments acknowledges the long-settled rule that courts possess inherent authority to initiate contempt proceedings for disobedience to their orders
column3: which authority necessarily includes the ability to appoint a private attorney to prosecute the contempt.  The contention that only the United States Attorney's Office may bring a contempt prosecution is unavailing
column4: since the Judiciary must have an independent means to vindicate

column1: its own authority without dependence on another Branch to decide whether proceedings should be initiated.  Pp.  481 U. S. 793-796.
(b) Courts' authority to initiate contempt prosecutions is not limited to the summary punishment of in-court contempts
column2: but extends to out-of-court contempts as well.  The underlying basis for the contempt power is the need to address disobedience to court orders regardless of whether such disobedience interferes with the conduct of trial.  The distinction between in-court and out-of-court contempts has been drawn not to define when a court has authority to initiate a contempt prosecution
column3: but to prescribe the procedures that must attend the exercise of that authority.  Thus
column4: although proceedings in response to out-of-court contempts are sufficiently criminal in nature to warrant the imposition of many procedural protections
column5: this does not mean that their prosecution can be undertaken only by the Executive Branch
column6: and it should not obscure the fact that the limited purpose of such proceedings is to vindicate judicial authority.  Pp.  481 U. S. 797-801.

column1: (c) In order to ensure that courts will exercise their inherent power of self-protection only as a last resort
column2: they should ordinarily request the appropriate prosecuting authority to prosecute contempt actions
column3: and should appoint a private prosecutor only if that request is denied.  Pp.  481 U. S. 801-802.

column1: 2. Counsel for a party that is the beneficiary of a court order may not be appointed to undertake criminal contempt prosecutions for alleged violations of that order.  A private attorney appointed to prosecute a criminal contempt should be as disinterested as a public prosecutor
column2: since the attorney is appointed solely to pursue the public interest in vindication of the court's authority.  In a case where a prosecutor also represents an interested party
column3: however
column4: the legal profession's ethical rules may require that the prosecutor take into account an interest other than the Government's.  This creates an intolerable danger that the public interest will be compromised
column5: and produces at least the appearance of impropriety.  The fact that the judge makes the initial decision to proceed with a contempt prosecution is not sufficient to quell concern that the interested prosecutor may be influenced by improper motives
column6: since the prosecutor exercises considerable discretion in matters that are critical to the
column7: case but outside the court's supervision.  The requirement of a disinterested prosecutor is consistent with this Court's earlier decisions recognizing that prosecutors need not be as disinterested as judges.  Most such cases require the court's informed speculation as to whether the prosecutor is subject to extraneous influence
column8: whereas such influence is a virtual certainty in cases such as the present.  Pp.  481 U. S. 802-809.

column2: joined by JUSTICE MARSHALL
column3: JUSTICE BLACKMUN
column4: and JUSTICE STEVENS
column5: concluded in Part III-B that the harmless

column1: error doctrine cannot apply when a court appoints counsel for an interested party as contempt prosecutor
column2: since such error is so fundamental and pervasive that it requires reversal without regard to the facts or circumstances of the particular case.  Pp.  481 U. S. 809-814.

column1: JUSTICE SCALIA concluded that the District Court's error in appointing respondent's attorneys to prosecute the contempts requires reversal of the convictions.  The appointments were defective because the federal courts have no constitutional power to prosecute contemners for disobedience of court judgments
column2: and no power derivative of that to appoint attorneys to conduct contempt prosecutions.  In light of the discretion allowed prosecutors
column3: which is so broad that decisions not to prosecute are ordinarily unreviewable
column4: it would be impossible to conclude with any certainty that these prosecutions would have been brought had the court simply referred the matter to the Executive Branch.  P.  481 U. S. 825.

column1: Title 8 U.S.C.  1326 provides that any alien who has been deported and thereafter enters the United States is guilty of a felony.  Respondents
column2: Mexican nationals
column3: were arrested and deported after a group hearing at which they purportedly waived their rights to apply for suspension of deportation and to appeal.  Subsequently
column4: respondents were again arrested in this country and indicted on charges of violating  1326.  However
column5: the District Court dismissed the indictments
column6: ruling that respondents could collaterally attack their previous deportation orders.  The court found that they had not understood the Immigration Judge's explanation of suspension of deportation
column7: and concluded that the reliability of the proceedings had been totally undermined by the fact that they had not made knowing and intelligent waivers of their right to that remedy or their right to appeal.  The Court of Appeals affirmed
column8: holding that
column9: since a material element of the offense prohibited by  1326 was a ""lawful"" deportation order
column10: principles of fundamental fairness required a pretrial review of the underlying deportation to determine whether respondents received due process of law.  Because they did not fully understand the proceedings
column11: the court found a due process violation rendering the deportation order unlawful
column12: and therefore not a proper basis for the charges against respondents.

column2: legislative history
column3: and background of  1326 indicate that Congress did not intend the validity of an underlying deportation order to be contestable in a  1326 prosecution.  Section 1326's express language does not suggest that only a ""lawful"" deportation may be an element of the offense
column4: thereby permitting a collateral challenge.  Moreover
column5: in enacting  1326
column6: Congress had available to it at least one predecessor statute containing express language that would have permitted collateral challenges
column7: but failed to include that language in  1326.  While there was
column8: at the time of  1326's enactment
column9: some case law suggesting that collateral attacks might be permissible under certain circumstances
column10: that principle was not so unequivocally established that Congress must have intended to incorporate it into  1326.  Furthermore
column11: the Immigration and Nationality Act does include sections -- particularly 8 U.S.C.  1105(a) -- dealing with judicial review of deportation

column2: which
column3: although not directly applicable to this case
column4: indicate that Congress considered and addressed some of the various circumstances in which challenges to deportation orders might arise without mentioning  1326.  Pp.  481 U. S. 833-837.

column1: 2. Due process requires that a collateral challenge to the use of a deportation proceeding as an element of a criminal offense be permitted where the deportation proceeding effectively eliminates the right of the alien to obtain judicial review.  Pp.  481 U. S. 837-842.
(a) Depriving an alien of the right to have the disposition of a deportation hearing reviewed in a judicial forum requires
column2: at a minimum
column3: that review be made available in any subsequent proceeding in which the result of the deportation proceeding is used to establish an element of a criminal offense.  Pp.  481 U. S. 837-839.

column1: (b) Respondents' deportation hearing was fundamentally unfair
column2: and violated due process.  By permitting waivers of the right to appeal that were not the result of considered or intelligent judgment by respondents
column3: the Immigration Judge completely deprived them of their right to judicial review of the deportation proceeding.  This deprivation precludes the use of the deportation orders to prove  1326 violations.  Pp.  481 U. S. 839-840.
is distinguishable from the instant case
column4: since it assumed the opportunity to challenge the underlying decision in a judicial forum
column5: precisely that which was denied respondents here.  Pp.  481 U. S. 840-842.

an electrical apprentice employed by Florida Power and Light Company (Florida Power)
column3: was injured while assigned to a job that required her to perform tasks allegedly beyond the scope of her training and experience.  She brought suit in a Florida court against petitioner unions (collectively referred to as the Union)
column4: alleging that
column5: ""pursuant to contracts and agreements"" between the Union and Florida Power
column6: ""to which . . . [she] was a third-party beneficiary
column7: and ""pursuant to the relationship by and between"" the Union and her
column8: the Union had a duty of care to ensure her a safe workplace
column9: which it had breached by allowing her to be assigned to work in a dangerous location.  The Union removed the action to federal court on the grounds that its alleged duty arose solely from the collective bargaining agreement
column10: and therefore that any breach of its duty was actionable solely under  301 of the Labor Management Relations Act
column11: 1947.  The Union then moved to dismiss the complaint as untimely under the applicable federal statute of limitations.  Respondent argued that the basic nature of her action was a state common-law ""suit in tort
column12: and prayed that the case be remanded to the state court.  The District Court granted the Union's motion to dismiss
column13: holding that the Union's alleged duty flowed from the collective bargaining agreement
column14: and that respondent's claim thus was preempted by  301
column15: and was untimely under federal law.  The Court of Appeals reversed.

column1: 1. Respondent's claim is not sufficiently independent of the collective bargaining agreement to withstand  301's preemptive force.  Pp.  481 U. S. 855-862.

(a) The interests in interpretive uniformity and predictability that require that labor contract disputes be resolved by reference to federal common law also require that the meaning given a contract phrase or term be subject to uniform federal interpretation
column2: whether the question arises in the context of a suit for breach of contract or in a suit alleging liability in tort.  Thus
column3: an employee's state law tort action that necessarily rests on an interpretation of terms in the collective bargaining

column1: agreement is preempted by  301.  Allis-Chalmers Corp. v. Lueck

column2: the employer
column3: not the labor union
column4: owes employees a duty to furnish a reasonably safe workplace.  A union may assume a responsibility to employees by accepting a duty of care through a contractual arrangement
column5: and
column6: under Florida law
column7: if a party breaches a contractual duty
column8: the aggrieved party may bring either an action for breach of contract or a tort action for the injury suffered as a result of the contractual breach.  However
column9: the threshold inquiry for determining if a cause of action exists is an examination of the contract to ascertain what duties were accepted by each of the parties and the scope of those duties.  Respondent's complaint alleges precisely this type of tortious breach of contract claim
column10: and her allegations of negligence are significant only if the Union
column12: assumed the duty of care that it allegedly breached.  Thus
column13: questions of contract interpretation underlie any finding of tort liability
column14: and respondent is precluded from evading  301's preemptive force by casting her claim as a state law tort action.  Pp.  481 U. S. 859-862.

column1: Supreme Court of the United States
On petition for writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit.
The application for stay of execution of the sentence of death
presented to Justice POWELL and by him referred to the Court is denied. The petition for a writ of certiorari is denied.

column2: with whom Justice MARSHALL joins
column3: dissenting.

column1: Adhering to my view that the death penalty is in all circumstances cruel and unusual punishment prohibited by the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments
column2: Gregg v. Georgia
column7: I would grant the application for stay of execution and the petition for certiorari
column8: and would vacate the death sentence in this case.

column1: Even if I did not take this view
column2: however
column3: I would still grant the application for a stay. Tucker's petition for certiorari raises the question whether inflammatory and prejudicial photographs of the victim's body introduced at trial violated his constitutional right to ""fundamental fairness and a reliable sentencing determination."" Pet. for Cert. i. This question is sufficiently similar to a question that will be decided by the Court in Thompson v. Oklahoma
column6: --- U.S . ___ 1 that the petition should be held by the Court pending our disposition of the question in Thompson. [Footnote 2]

column1: I find particularly disturbing the Court of Appeals' treatment of this question. In deciding that the grant of certiorari in Thompson did not ""sufficiently suggest that 'new law' relevant to the present case [was] near at hand
column2: the court stated:
any doubt that the Court of Appeals had about which issue prompted the Court to grant certiorari should have been resolved in favor of the defendant facing the death penalty. Moreover
column3: given that this Court may restrict its grant of certiorari to those questions it wishes to hear
column4: it seems to me most inappropriate for the court to have engaged in speculation about the possible insignificance of our grant on one of the questions in Tucker's petition.

column1: The relationship between the questions presented by Tucker and Thompson justifies delaying consideration of the former on the ground that it will be illuminated by the disposition of the latter. I dissent.
Footnote 1 Among the questions presented in Thompson is:
Footnote 2 It is true that in Thompson the court below found that admission of the photographs at issue was error
column2: but harmless
column3: while here the court found no error in the admission of the photographs. This difference is not significant. In Thompson
column4: in order to overturn the State court's determination of harmless error
column5: we would have to find both that the admission of the photographs at issue violated the defendant's due process rights under the Federal Constitution
column6: and that the error was not harmless . In order to overturn the State Court's determination that no error occurred in Tucker
column7: we would have to find only the first of these
column8: namely that the admission of the photographs at issue violated these same Federal Constitutional rights. Plainly
column9: any standard we might develop in deciding whether sufficient prejudice existed to render an error harmful would be applicable in a decision whether sufficient possibility of prejudice existed to render admission of evidence error. The possibility that the analysis in Thompson will shed light on Tucker is therefore sufficient to justify a hold.

column1: Respondent was convicted of second-degree murder and sentenced to life imprisonment in a Pennsylvania trial court
column2: and the Pennsylvania Supreme Court affirmed on direct appeal.  In respondent's subsequent postconviction proceedings
column3: the trial court
column4: as required by state law
column5: appointed counsel to assist her.  Counsel reviewed the trial record; consulted with respondent; concluded that there were no arguable bases for collateral review; advised the trial court in writing of his conclusion; and requested permission to withdraw.  After reviewing the record
column6: the court agreed that there were no arguably meritorious issues and dismissed the proceedings.  Respondent acquired new appointed counsel and appealed to the Pennsylvania Superior Court
column7: which concluded that counsel's conduct in the trial court violated respondent's constitutional rights
column8: and remanded the case for further proceedings.  The Superior Court relied on Anders v. California
column10: which held that (1) when an attorney appointed to represent an indigent defendant on direct appeal finds the case to be wholly frivolous
column11: he must request the court's permission to withdraw and submit a brief referring to anything in the record arguably supporting the appeal
column12: (2) a copy of the brief must be furnished the indigent
column13: and time must be allowed for him to raise any points that he chooses
column14: and (3) the court itself must then decide whether the case is wholly frivolous.

column1: Held:  The court below improperly relied on the Federal Constitution to extend the Anders procedures to these collateral postconviction proceedings.  Denial of counsel to indigents on first appeal as of right amounts to discrimination against the poor in violation of the Fourteenth Amendment
column2: and Anders established a prophylactic framework that is relevant when
column3: and only when
column4: a litigant has a previously established Constitutional right to counsel.  The right to appointed counsel extends to only the first appeal of right
column5: and
column6: since a defendant has no federal constitutional right to counsel when pursuing a discretionary appeal on direct review of his conviction
column7: Ross v. Moffitt
column9: a fortiorari
column10: he has no such right when attacking
column12: a conviction that has become final upon exhaustion of the appellate process.  The Anders procedures do not apply to a state-created right to counsel on postconviction review just because they are applied to the right to counsel on first appeal as of right. Respondent's access to a lawyer was the

column2: not the command of the Federal Constitution.  The procedures followed by her trial counsel in the postconviction proceedings fully comported with the fundamental fairness mandated by the Due Process Clause.  States have no obligation to provide postconviction relief
column3: and when they do
column4: the fundamental fairness mandated by the Due Process Clause does not require that the State supply a lawyer as well.  Nor was the equal protection guarantee of meaningful access violated in this case.  Moreover
column5: there is no merit to respondent's contention that
column6: once the State has granted a prisoner access to counsel on postconviction review
column7: the Due Process Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment requires that counsel's actions comport with the Anders procedures.  Evitts v. Lucey
column9: distinguished.  Pennsylvania made a valid choice to give prisoners the assistance of counsel in postconviction proceedings without requiring the full panoply of procedural protections that the Constitution requires be given to defendants who are in a fundamentally different position -- at trial and on first appeal as of right.  Pp.  481 U. S. 554-559.

column3: reversed and remanded.

column5: (2) under the ""reservoir doctrine

column1: (a) The State Supreme Court's analysis is rejected if and to the extent it is based on the reasoning that the trial judge restored one of the State's peremptory challenges by determining that he had erred in denying one of the Witherspoon motions

column2: Fourth Appellate District.

column1: The motion of respondent Ronald Lee Sabo for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted. The motion of respondent Angela Marie Zizzo for leave to proceed in forma pauperis is granted. The petition for a writ of certiorari is denied.

column2: with whom THE CHIEF JUSTICE joins
column3: dissenting.

column1: During a routine helicopter patrol a deputy sheriff observed what he believed to be marijuana plants growing inside a 15 by 20 foot greenhouse located in respondents' back yard. The helicopter hovered at 400 to 500 feet and circled the greenhouse in order to give the deputy a better look at the marijuana. Based on this observation a search warrant issued and deputies seized the marijuana. A trial court held the marijuana inadmissible as evidence and the California Court of Appeals affirmed
column2: holding that the deputy's observation of the greenhouse from the hovering helicopter violated the Fourth Amendment. People v. Sabo
column3: 185 Cal.App.3d 845
column4: 230 Cal.Rptr. 170 (1986). The Court of Appeals distinguished California v. Ciraolo
column6: on the ground that there the observation of marijuana was made from a fixed-wing aircraft flying in navigable airspace at an altitude over 1
column7: 000 feet. The court concluded that here the helicopter was not in navigable airspace as that term is defined at 49 U.S.C. 1301(29)
column8: but recognized that the helicopter was lawfully positioned because federal regulations allow operation of helicopters at altitudes less than the minimum permitted to fixed-wing aircraft
column9: [ California v. Sabo 481 U.S. 1058 (1987) ][1058-Continued.]

column1: provided that the helicopter operates without hazard to persons or property
column2: see 14 CFR 91.79(d) (1986).* The court expressed concern about the capabilities of helicopters to furnish ""a platform for aerial surveillance
column3: id.
column4: 230 Cal.Rptr. at 175
column5: and held that the search in this case infringed on a reasonable expectation of privacy.

column1: The Court of Appeals' holding that the helicopter was not in navigable airspace is questionable
column2: and even if this is technically correct it remains true
column3: as the court conceded
column4: that the helicopter was lawfully positioned when the deputy observed the marijuana in respondents' greenhouse. While it is certainly possible that helicopter surveillance could be unreasonably intrusive on account of interminable hovering
column5: raising clouds of dust
column6: creating unreasonable noise
column7: and so forth
column8: nothing in the record indicates that any such factor was present in this case. The decision below is a highly questionable interpretation of our decision in California v. Ciraolo. I would grant certiorari.

column1: [Footnote *] Title 49 U.S.C. 1301(29) defines navigable airspace as ""airspace above the minimum altitudes of flight prescribed by regulations issued under this chapter
column2: . . . includ[ing] airspace needed to insure safety in take-off and landing of aircraft."" The Court of Appeals reasoned that a helicopter flying below 1000 feet is not above a specified minimum flight altitude and hence not in navigable airspace.

column1: After being advised of his Miranda rights while in custody for killing his son
column2: respondent stated that he did not wish to answer any questions until a lawyer was present.  All questioning then ceased and respondent was placed in the police captain's office
column3: since there was no secure detention area.  Following her questioning in another room
column4: respondent's wife insisted that she be allowed to speak with her husband.  Although reluctant at first
column5: the police allowed the meeting in the office on the condition that an officer be present.  Using a recorder placed in plain sight
column6: the officer taped a brief conversation
column7: during which the wife expressed despair
column8: and respondent told her not to answer questions until a lawyer was present.  The prosecution used the tape to rebut respondent's insanity defense
column9: the trial court having refused to suppress it upon finding that the police's actions were not a subterfuge to avoid the dictates of Miranda.  Respondent was convicted and sentenced to death
column10: but the Arizona Supreme Court reversed
column11: holding that the police had impermissibly interrogated respondent within the meaning of Miranda.  Noting police admissions that they knew it was ""possible"" that respondent might make incriminating statements if he saw his wife
column12: the court relied on the ruling in Rhode Island v. Innis
column14: that ""interrogation"" includes a practice -- whether actual questioning or ""its functional equivalent"" -- that the police know is reasonably likely to elicit an incriminating response from a suspect.  According to Innis

column1: Held:  The police's actions following respondent's refusal to be questioned without a lawyer did not constitute interrogation or its functional equivalent.  The purpose of Miranda and Innis is to prevent the government from using the coercive nature of confinement to extract confessions that would not be given in an unrestrained environment.  This purpose is not implicated here
column2: since respondent was not subjected to compelling influences
column3: psychological ploys
column4: or direct questioning.  There is no evidence that the police allowed the wife to meet with respondent in order to obtain incriminating statements.  Moreover
column5: police testimony
column6: which the trial court found credible
column7: indicated a number of legitimate reasons for an officer's presence at the meeting
column8: including the wife's safety and various security considerations.  Furthermore
column9: an examination of the situation

column4: professional
column5: and institutional activity in the community.  Although women are permitted to attend meetings
column6: give speeches

column19: and services in all business establishments in the State.  The state trial court entered judgment for Rotary International

column1: 1. The Unruh Act does not violate the First Amendment by requiring California Rotary Clubs to admit women.  Pp.  481 U. S. 544-549.

column2: consideration must be given to factors such as size
column3: purpose
column4: selectivity
column5: and whether others are excluded from critical aspects of the relationship.  Here
column6: the relationship among Rotary Club members does not warrant protection
column7: in light of the potentially large size of local clubs
column8: the high turnover rate among club members
column9: the inclusive nature of each club's membership
column10: the public purposes behind clubs' service activities
column11: and the fact that the clubs encourage the

column2: and welcome media coverage of

column3: the Act does not require clubs to abandon or alter their classification and admission systems
column4: but
column5: in fact

column7: that infringement is justified by the State's compelling interests in eliminating discrimination against women and in assuring them equal access to public accommodations.  The latter interest extends to the acquisition of leadership skills and business contacts
column8: as well as tangible goods and services.  Pp.  481 U. S. 548-549.

column1: The Clean Water Act (Act) authorizes injunctive relief against violators (33 U.S.C.  1319(b)) and subjects them to a civil penalty not to exceed $10
column2: 000 per day ( 1319(d)).  After denying petitioner's timely demand for a jury trial in the Government's suit for relief under  1319(b) and 1319(d)
column3: the District Court imposed civil penalties and granted injunctive relief against petitioner.  The Court of Appeals affirmed
column4: rejecting petitioner's argument that the Seventh Amendment entitled him to a jury trial on the civil penalties claim.  The court held
column5: inter alia
column6: that the District Court had exercised statutorily conferred equitable power in assessing monetary penalties.

column1: 1. The Seventh Amendment guarantees a jury trial to determine liability in actions by the Government seeking civil penalties and injunctive relief under the Act.  An examination of the nature of such actions and of the remedies sought demonstrates that they are more analogous to ""Suits at common law"" within the meaning of the Amendment than they are to cases traditionally tried in courts of equity.  Pp.  481 U. S. 417-425.
(a) A Government suit under  1319(d) is analogous to an action in debt within the jurisdiction of English courts of law prior to the Seventh Amendment's enactment
column2: and therefore should be tried by a jury.  The Government's argument that the action is more analogous to an action by the English sovereign to abate a public nuisance is debatable
column3: but irrelevant for Seventh Amendment purposes
column4: since that Amendment requires trial by jury in actions unheard of at common law.  Both a public nuisance action and an action in debt could be asserted by the sovereign to seek relief for an injury to the public in numerous contexts.  The conclusion that both are appropriate analogies to a  1319(d) action is sufficient here
column5: particularly in light of the Court's characterization of the relief sought infra.  Pp.  481 U. S. 418-421.

column1: (b) Unlike public nuisance actions which relied on the injunctive relief provided by equity courts
column2: the text and legislative history of  1319(d) demonstrate that suits thereunder are intended to punish culpable individuals
column3: and thus yield a type of remedy that at common law could only be enforced in a court of law.  The contention that a  1319(d) suit is similar to an equitable action for disgorgement of profits is not persuasive
column4: since the latter is a remedy only for restitution
column5: a more limited

column1: form of relief than a civil penalty.  The Government's contention that its  1319(b) injunction action provides jurisdiction for incidental monetary relief without the necessity of a jury trial also fails
column2: since equity courts may not enforce civil penalties
column3: and the Government knew when it filed suit that relief would be limited primarily to civil penalties
column4: because petitioner had already sold most of the property at issue.  The potential penalty of $23 million could hardly be considered ""incidental"" to the modest equitable relief sought.  Moreover
column5: the Government was free to pursue its  1319(b) claim independent of its  1319(d) claim.  By choosing to combine them
column6: it preserved petitioner's right to a jury trial on the legal claim and all issues common to both claims
column7: and cannot abridge that right by characterizing the legal claim as ""incidental.""  Pp.  481 U. S. 422-425.

column1: 2. The Seventh Amendment does not guarantee a jury trial to assess civil penalties under the Act.  The fact that trial judges assess those penalties does not violate the Amendment
column2: since assessment cannot be Said to involve the substance of a common law right to

column5: as is necessary to implicate the Amendment.  Congress has an unquestioned right to fix civil penalties
column6: and may delegate that right to trial judges
column7: particularly where
column8: as here
column9: highly discretionary calculations that take into account multiple factors are necessary.  Pp.  481 U. S. 425-427.

column1: Arkansas imposes a tax on receipts from sales of tangible personal property
column2: but exempts numerous items
column3: including newspapers and ""religious
column4: professional
column5: trade
column6: and sports journals and/or publications printed and published within this State"" (magazine exemption).  Appellant publishes in Arkansas a general interest magazine that includes articles on a variety of subjects
column7: including religion and sports.  In 1984
column8: relying on Minneapolis Star & Tribune Co. v. Minnesota Comm'r of Revenue
column10: appellant sought a refund of sales tax it had paid since 1982
column11: asserting that the magazine exemption must be construed to include its magazine
column12: and that subjecting its magazine to the sales tax
column13: while sales of newspapers and other magazines were exempt
column14: violated the First and Fourteenth Amendments.  After appellee denied the refund claim
column15: appellant sought review in State Chancery Court
column16: stating an additional claim under 42 U.S.C.  1983 and 1988 for injunctive relief and attorney's fees.  That court granted appellant summary judgment
column17: construing the magazine exemption to include appellant because its magazine was published and printed in Arkansas.  The Arkansas Supreme Court reversed
column18: holding that the magazine exemption applies only to religious
column21: or sports periodicals.  The court rejected the claim that the exemption granted to other publications discriminated against appellant
column22: ruling that success on this claim would avail appellant nothing
column23: since it would still be subject to tax even if the exemption fell.  The court also refused to find that appellant's First and Fourteenth Amendment rights had been violated
column24: ruling that the sales tax was a permissible ""ordinary form of taxation"" to which publishers are not immune.  Accordingly
column25: the court did not consider appellant's attorney's fees claim.

column1: 1. Appellant has standing to challenge the Arkansas sales tax scheme.  Appellee's argument that appellant has not asserted an injury that this Court can redress
column2: since appellant concededly publishes neither a newspaper nor a religious
column3: professional
column4: trade
column5: or sports journal
column6: is unpersuasive
column7: since it would effectively insulate underinclusive statutes from constitutional challenge.  Appellant has alleged a sufficient personal stake in this litigation's outcome
column8: in that the State Supreme Court's holding stands as a total bar to appellant's relief
column9: and its constitutional attack

column1: holds the only promise of escape from the burden imposed upon it by the challenged statute.  P.  481 U. S. 227.
2. The Arkansas sales tax scheme that taxes general interest magazines
column2: but exempts newspapers and religious
column3: professional
column4: trade
column5: and sports journals
column6: violates the First Amendment's freedom of the press guarantee.  Pp.  481 U. S. 227-234.

column1: (a) Even though there is no evidence of an improper censorial motive
column2: the Arkansas tax burdens rights protected by the First Amendment by discriminating against a small group of magazines
column3: including appellant's
column4: which are the only magazines that pay the tax.  Such selective taxation is one of the types of discrimination identified in Minneapolis Star.  Indeed
column5: its use here is even more disturbing than in that case
column6: because the Arkansas statute requires official scrutiny of publications' content as the basis for imposing a tax.  This is incompatible with the First Amendment
column7: whose requirements are not avoided merely because the statute does not burden the expression of particular views expressed by specific magazines
column8: and exempts other members of the media that might publish discussions of the various subjects contained in appellant's magazine.  Pp.  481 U. S. 227-231.

column1: (b) Appellee has not satisfied its heavy burden of showing that its discriminatory tax scheme is necessary to serve a compelling state interest
column2: and is narrowly drawn to achieve that end.  The State's general interest in raising revenue does not justify selective imposition of the sales tax on some magazines and not others
column3: based solely on their content
column4: since revenues could be raised simply by taxing businesses generally.  Furthermore
column5: appellee's assertion that the magazine exemption serves the state interest of encouraging ""fledgling"" publishers is not persuasive
column6: since the exemption is not narrowly tailored to achieve that end.  To the contrary
column7: the exemption is both overinclusive and underinclusive in that it exempts the enumerated types of magazines regardless of whether they are ""fledgling"" or are lucrative and well established
column8: while making general interest magazines and struggling specialty magazines on other subjects ineligible for favorable tax treatment.  Moreover
column9: although the asserted state need to ""foster communication"" might support a blanket exemption of the press from the sales tax
column10: it cannot justify selective taxation of certain publishers.  Pp.  481 U. S. 231-232.

column1: 3. Since the state courts have not yet indicated whether they will exercise jurisdiction over appellant's claims under  1983 and 1988
column2: this Court remands to give them an opportunity to do so.  Pp.  481 U. S. 233-234.

column3: reversed and remanded.

column3: an accrual-basis taxpayer is entitled to deduct a business expense for the taxable year in which all events have occurred which determine the fact of the taxpayer's liability
column4: and in which the amount of that liability can be determined with reasonable accuracy.  In the year at issue
column5: a consolidated federal income tax return was filed by General Dynamics Corporation and several of its wholly owned subsidiaries (hereafter respondent).  Respondent is an accrual-basis taxpayer whose fiscal year is the calendar year.  Beginning in 1972
column6: it became a self-insurer with regard to its employee medical care plan.  To receive medical payment reimbursements
column7: employees must submit claims forms to employee benefits personnel
column8: who verify eligibility and forward worthy claims to the plan's administrators
column9: whose claims processors review the claims and approve covered expenses for payment.  To account for the delay between the provision of medical services and the payment of claims
column10: respondent established reserve accounts reflecting its liability for medical care received
column14: respondent sought a refund based on its claimed deduction of its reserve as an accrued expense.  The Internal Revenue Service disallowed the deduction
column15: but the Claims Court sustained it
column16: holding that ""all events"" which determined the fact of respondent's liability had taken place when its employees received covered services
column17: and that the amount of liability could be determined with reasonable accuracy.  The Court of Appeals affirmed.

column1: Held:  Where the filing of claims is a condition precedent to liability
column2: an accrual-basis taxpayer providing medical benefits to its employees cannot deduct at the close of the taxable year an estimate of its obligation to pay for medical care obtained by employees or their qualified dependents during the final quarter of the year
column3: claims for which have not been reported to the employer.  Pp.  481 U. S. 242-247.

column1: (a) The proposed deduction fails the ""all events"" test
column2: because it depends on a mere estimate of respondent's liability based on events that had not occurred before the close of the 1972 taxable year.  The last event necessary to fix respondent's liability was not the receipt of medical
but the filing of properly documented claims forms.  Such filing is not a mere technicality
column3: nor is the possibility that some employees might not file claims after receiving services ""extremely remote and speculative.""  Pp.  481 U. S. 242-245.

column1: (b) Respondent has not demonstrated that its liability as to any medical care claims was firmly established as of the close of the 1972 taxable year.  Although the parties stipulated that respondent had not received claims for all services rendered during the year by the year's end
column2: and that some claims received had not been processed at that time
column3: respondent failed to show what portion of the claims had been filed by the end of the year
column4: or even that it knew of specific claims that had been filed
column5: but not yet processed.  The fact that respondent may have been able to make a reasonably accurate actuarial estimate of how many claims would be filed for the last quarter of 1972 cannot justify a deduction.  If the ""all events"" test permitted such a deduction
column6: Congress would not have retained 26 U.S.C.  832(b)(5)
column7: which allows insurance companies to deduct additions to reserves for ""incurred but not reported"" claims.  Pp.  481 U. S. 245-247.

column2: petitioner
column3: a black man
column4: was convicted in a Georgia trial court of armed robbery and murder
column5: arising from the killing of a white police officer during the robbery of a store.  Pursuant to Georgia statutes
column6: the jury at the penalty hearing considered the mitigating and aggravating circumstances of petitioner's conduct
column7: and recommended the death penalty on the murder charge.  The trial court followed the recommendation
column8: and the Georgia Supreme Court affirmed.  After unsuccessfully seeking postconviction relief in state courts
column9: petitioner sought habeas corpus relief in Federal District Court.  His petition included a claim that the Georgia capital sentencing process was administered in a racially discriminatory manner in violation of the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments.  In support of the claim
column10: petitioner proffered a statistical study (the Baldus study) that purports to show a disparity in the imposition of the death sentence in Georgia based on the murder victim's race and
column12: the defendant's race.  The study is based on over 2
column13: 000 murder cases that occurred in Georgia during the 1970's
column14: and involves data relating to the victim's race
column16: and the various combinations of such persons' races.  The study indicates that black defendants who killed white victims have the greatest likelihood of receiving the death penalty.  Rejecting petitioner's constitutional claims
column17: the court denied his petition insofar as it was based on the Baldus study
column18: and the Court of Appeals affirmed the District Court's decision on this issue.  It assumed the validity of the Baldus study
column19: but found the statistics insufficient to demonstrate unconstitutional discrimination in the Fourteenth Amendment context or to show irrationality
column21: and capriciousness under Eighth Amendment analysis.

column1: 1. The Baldus study does not establish that the administration of the Georgia capital punishment system violates the Equal Protection Clause.  Pp.  481 U. S. 291-299.

column2: petitioner must prove that the decisionmakers in his case acted with discriminatory purpose.  Petitioner offered no evidence specific to his own case that would support an

column1: inference that racial considerations played a part in his sentence
column2: and the Baldus study is insufficient to support an inference that any of the decisionmakers in his case acted with discriminatory purpose.  This Court has accepted statistics as proof of intent to discriminate in the context of a State's selection of the jury venire
column3: and in the context of statutory violations under Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964.  However
column4: the nature of the capital sentencing decision and the relationship of the statistics to that decision are fundamentally different from the corresponding elements in the venire selection or Title VII cases.  Petitioner's statistical proffer must be viewed in the context of his challenge to decisions at the heart of the State's criminal justice system.  Because discretion is essential to the criminal justice process
column5: exceptionally clear proof is required before this Court will infer that the discretion has been abused.  Pp.  481 U. S. 292-297.

column1: (b) There is no merit to petitioner's argument that the Baldus study proves that the State has violated the Equal Protection Clause by adopting the capital punishment statute and allowing it to remain in force despite its allegedly discriminatory application.  For this claim to prevail
column2: petitioner would have to prove that the Georgia Legislature enacted or maintained the death penalty statute because of an anticipated racially discriminatory effect.  There is no evidence that the legislature either enacted the statute to further a racially discriminatory purpose or maintained the statute because of the racially disproportionate impact suggested by the Baldus study.  Pp.  481 U. S. 297-299.

column1: 2. Petitioner's argument that the Baldus study demonstrates that the Georgia capital sentencing system violates the Eighth Amendment's prohibition of cruel and unusual punishment must be analyzed in the light of this Court's prior decisions under that Amendment.  Decisions since Furman v. Georgia
column3: have identified a constitutionally permissible range of discretion in imposing the death penalty.  First
column4: there is a required threshold below which the death penalty cannot be imposed
column5: and the State must establish rational criteria that narrow the decisionmaker's judgment as to whether the circumstances of a particular defendant's case meet the threshold.  Second
column6: States cannot limit the sentencer's consideration of any relevant circumstance that could cause it to decline to impose the death penalty.  In this respect
column7: the State cannot channel the sentencer's discretion
column8: but must allow it to consider any relevant information offered by the defendant.  Pp.  481 U. S. 299-306.

column1: 3. The Baldus study does not demonstrate that the Georgia capital sentencing system violates the Eighth Amendment.  Pp.  481 U. S. 306-313.
(a) Petitioner cannot successfully argue that the sentence in his case is disproportionate to the sentences in other murder cases.  On the one

column2: he cannot base a constitutional claim on an argument that his case differs from other cases in which defendants did receive the death penalty.  The Georgia Supreme Court found that his death sentence was not disproportionate to other death sentences imposed in the State.  On the other hand
column3: absent a showing that the Georgia capital punishment system operates in an arbitrary and capricious manner
column4: petitioner cannot prove a constitutional violation by demonstrating that other defendants who may be similarly situated did not receive the death penalty.  The opportunities for discretionary leniency under state law do not render the capital sentences imposed arbitrary and capricious.  Because petitioner's sentence was imposed under Georgia sentencing procedures that focus discretion ""on the particularized nature of the crime and the particularized characteristics of the individual defendant
column5: it may be presumed that his death sentence was not ""wantonly and freakishly"" imposed
column6: and thus that the sentence is not disproportionate within any recognized meaning under the Eighth Amendment.  Gregg v. Georgia

column1: (b) There is no merit to the contention that the Baldus study shows that Georgia's capital punishment system is arbitrary and capricious in application.  The statistics do not prove that race enters into any capital sentencing decisions or that race was a factor in petitioner's case.  The likelihood of racial prejudice allegedly shown by the study does not constitute the constitutional measure of an unacceptable risk of racial prejudice.  The inherent lack of predictability of jury decisions does not justify their condemnation.  On the contrary
column2: it is the jury's function to make the difficult and uniquely human judgments that defy codification and that build discretion
column3: equity
column4: and flexibility into the legal system.  Pp.  481 U. S. 308-312.

column2: the Baldus study indicates a discrepancy that appears to correlate with race
column3: but this discrepancy does not constitute a major systemic defect.  Any mode for determining guilt or punishment has its weaknesses and the potential for misuse.  Despite such imperfections
column4: constitutional guarantees are met when the mode for determining guilt or punishment has been surrounded with safeguards to make it as fair as possible.  Pp.  481 U. S. 312-313.

column3: throws into serious question the principles that underlie the entire criminal justice system.  His claim easily could be extended to apply to other types of penalties and to claims based on unexplained discrepancies correlating to membership in other minority groups and even to gender.  The Constitution does not require that a State eliminate any demonstrable disparity that correlates with a potentially irrelevant factor in order to

column2: not the courts.  Pp.  481 U. S. 314-319.

column5: although introduction of the defendant's own interlocking confession cannot cure the Confrontation Clause violation caused by introduction of the nontestifying codefendant's confession
column6: it might
column7: in some cases

column9: when the defendant has himself confessed
column10: introduction of the codefendant's confession will seldom
column12: be of the ""devastating"" character required by Bruton to prove a Confrontation Clause violation.  Although Bruton did consider ""devastating"" effect
column13: it did so in the context of justification for excluding the entire category of codefendant confessions that implicate the defendant
column14: and not as a factor whose existence must be assessed on a case-by-case basis.  The assumption

column1: that an interlocking confession precludes devastation is rendered untenable by the infinite variability of inculpatory statements and their likely effect on juries.  In fact
column2: ""interlocking"" bears an inverse relationship to devastation
column3: since a codefendant's confession that corroborates the defendant's alleged confession significantly harms the defendant's case
column4: whereas one that is positively incompatible gives credence to the defendant's assertion that his own alleged confession was nonexistent or false.  The ""interlocking"" nature of a codefendant's confession pertains not to its harmfulness but to its reliability

Although petitioner's complaint in his hybrid suit against respondents -- his employer
column6: his union

column1: Held:  The action was timely commenced because the complaint was filed within the 6-month period.  When the underlying cause of action is based on federal law and the absence of an express federal statute of limitations makes it necessary for a federal court to borrow a limitations period from another statute
column2: the action is not barred if it has been ""commenced"" within the borrowed time period by the filing of a complaint with the court in compliance with Rule 3 of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure. column3: since Rules 4(a) and (j) of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure normally require the plaintiff to serve the summons and a copy of the complaint within 120 days.  When borrowing a statute of limitations for a federal cause of action
column4: this Court borrows no more than is necessary to fill a gap left by Congress.  DelCostello simply borrowed  10(b)'s limitations period
column5: and did not substitute  10(b) for the Federal Rules.  Pp.  481 U. S. 38-40.

column1: preemption.  A common-sense understanding of the language of the saving clause excepting from preemption a state law that ""regulates insurance"" does not support the argument that the Mississippi law of bad faith falls under the clause.  To ""regulate"" insurance
column2: a law must not just have an impact on the insurance industry
column3: but must be specifically directed toward that industry.  Mississippi Supreme Court decisions establish that its law of bad faith applies to any breach of contract

column2: interpretation of the saving clause must be informed by the legislative intent concerning ERISA's civil enforcement provisions.  The language and structure of those provisions support the conclusion that they were intended to provide exclusive remedies for ERISA-plan participants and beneficiaries asserting improper processing of benefit claims.  ERISA's detailed provisions set forth a comprehensive civil enforcement scheme that represents a careful balancing of the need for prompt and fair claims settlement procedures against the public interest in encouraging the formation of employee benefit plans.  The policy choices reflected in the inclusion of certain remedies and the exclusion of others under the federal scheme would be completely undermined if ERISA-plan participants and beneficiaries were free to obtain remedies under state law that Congress rejected in ERISA.  The conclusion that ERISA's civil enforcement provisions were intended to be exclusive is also confirmed by the legislative history of those provisions
column3: particularly the history demonstrating that the preemptive force of ERISA's enforcement provisions was modeled after the powerful preemptive force of  301 of the Labor Management Relations Act

column2: a physician and psychiatrist
column3: was an employee of a state hospital and had primary responsibility for training physicians in the psychiatric residency program.  Hospital officials became concerned about possible improprieties in his management of the program
column4: particularly with respect to his acquisition of a computer and charges against him concerning sexual harassment of female hospital employees and inappropriate disciplinary action against a resident.  While he was on administrative leave pending investigation of the charges
column5: hospital officials
column6: allegedly in order to inventory and secure state property
column7: searched his office and seized personal items from his desk and file cabinets that were used in administrative proceedings resulting in his discharge.  No formal inventory of the property in the office was ever made
column8: and all the other papers in the office were merely placed in boxes for storage.  Respondent filed an action against petitioner hospital officials in Federal District Court under 42 U.S.C. 1983
column9: alleging that the search of his office violated the Fourth Amendment.  On cross-motions for summary judgment
column10: the District Court granted judgment for petitioners
column11: concluding that the search was proper because there was a need to secure state property in the office.  Affirming in part
column14: the Court of Appeals concluded that respondent had a reasonable expectation of privacy in his office
column15: and that the search violated the Fourth Amendment.  The court held that the record justified a grant of partial summary judgment for respondent on the issue of liability for the search
column16: and it remanded the case to the District Court for a determination of damages.

column2: and the case is remanded.
reversed and remanded.
joined by THE CHIEF JUSTICE
column3: JUSTICE WHITE
column4: and JUSTICE POWELL
column5: concluded that:

column1: 1. Searches and seizures by government employers or supervisors of the private property of their employees are subject to Fourth Amendment restraints.  An expectation of privacy in one's place of work is based upon societal expectations that have deep roots in the history of the Amendment.  However
column2: the operational realities of the workplace may make some public employees' expectations of privacy unreasonable

column1: when an intrusion is by a supervisor
column2: rather than a law enforcement official.  Some government offices may be so open to fellow employees or the public that no expectation of privacy is reasonable.  Given the great variety of work environments in the public sector
column3: the question whether an employee has a reasonable expectation of privacy must be addressed on a case-by-case basis.  Because the record does not reveal the extent to which hospital officials may have had work-related reasons to enter respondent's office
column4: the Court of Appeals should have remanded the matter to the District Court for its further determination.  However
column5: a majority of this Court agrees with the determination of the Court of Appeals that respondent had a reasonable expectation of privacy in his office.  Regardless of any expectation of privacy in the office itself
column6: the undisputed evidence supports the conclusion that respondent had a reasonable expectation of privacy at least in his desk and file cabinets.  Pp.  480 U. S. 714-719.

column1: 2. In determining the appropriate standard for a search conducted by a public employer in areas in which an employee has a reasonable expectation of privacy
column2: what is a reasonable search depends on the context within which the search takes place
column3: and requires balancing the employee's legitimate expectation of privacy against the government's need for supervision
column4: control
column5: and the efficient operation of the workplace.  Requiring an employer to obtain a warrant whenever the employer wishes to enter an employee's office
column6: desk
column7: or file cabinets for a work-related purpose would seriously disrupt the routine conduct of business and would be unreasonable.  Moreover
column8: requiring a probable cause standard for searches of the type at issue here would impose intolerable burdens on public employers.  Their intrusions on the constitutionally protected privacy interests of government employees for noninvestigatory
column9: work-related purposes
column10: as well as for investigations of work-related misconduct
column11: should be judged by the standard of reasonableness under all the circumstances.  Under this standard
column12: both the inception and the scope of the intrusion must be reasonable.  Pp.  480 U. S. 719-726.

column1: 3. In the procedural posture of this case
column2: it cannot be determined whether the search of respondent's office
column3: and the seizure of his personal belongings
column4: satisfied the standard of reasonableness.  Both courts below were in error
column5: because summary judgment was inappropriate.  The parties were in dispute about the actual justification for the search
column6: and the record was inadequate for a determination of the reasonableness of the search and seizure.  On remand
column7: the District Court must determine these matters.  Pp.  480 U. S. 726-729.

column1: JUSTICE SCALIA concluded that the offices of government employees
column2: and a fortiori the drawers and files within those offices
column3: are covered by Fourth Amendment protections as a general matter
column4: and no special circumstances

column1: were present here that would call for an exception to the ordinary rule.  However
column2: government searches to retrieve work-related materials or to investigate violations of workplace rules -- searches of the sort that are regarded as reasonable and normal in the private employer context -- do not violate the Fourth Amendment.  Because the conflicting and incomplete evidence in the present case could not conceivably support summary judgment that the search did not have such a validating purpose
column3: the decision must be reversed and remanded.  Pp.  480 U. S. 731-732.

column2: an Affirmative Action Plan (Plan) for hiring and promoting minorities and women was voluntarily adopted by respondent Santa Clara County Transportation Agency (Agency).  The Plan provides
column3: inter alia
column4: that
column5: in making promotions to positions within a traditionally segregated job classification in which women have been significantly underrepresented
column6: the Agency is authorized to consider as one factor the sex of a qualified applicant.  The Plan is intended to achieve a statistically measurable yearly improvement in hiring and promoting minorities and women in job classifications where they are underrepresented
column7: and the long-term goal is to attain a workforce whose composition reflects the proportion of minorities and women in the area labor force.  The Plan sets aside no specific number of positions for minorities or women
column8: but requires that short-range goals be established and annually adjusted to serve as the most realistic guide for actual employment decisions.  When the Agency announced a vacancy for the promotional position of road dispatcher
column9: none of the 238 positions in the pertinent Skilled Craft Worker job classification
column11: was held by a woman.  The qualified applicants for the position were interviewed and the Agency
column17: both of whom were rated as well qualified for the job.  After receiving a right-to-sue letter from the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission
column18: petitioner filed suit in Federal District Court
column19: which held that the Agency had violated Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964.  The court found that Joyce's sex was the determining factor in her selection
column20: and that the Agency's Plan was invalid under the criterion announced in Steelworkers v. Weber
column22: that the Plan be temporary.  The Court of Appeals reversed.

column1: Held:  The Agency appropriately took into account Joyce's sex as one factor in determining that she should be promoted.  The Agency's Plan represents a moderate
column2: flexible
column3: case-by-case approach to effecting a gradual improvement in the representation of minorities and women

column2: and is fully consistent with Title VII.  Pp.  480 U. S. 626-640.

column1: (a) Petitioner bears the burden of proving that the Agency's Plan violates Title VII.  Once a plaintiff establishes a prima facie case that race or sex has been taken into account in an employer's employment decision
column2: the burden shifts to the employer to articulate a nondiscriminatory rationale for its decision
column3: such as the existence of an affirmative action plan.  The burden then shifts to the plaintiff to prove that the plan is invalid and that the employer's justification is pretextual.  Pp.  480 U. S. 626-627.

column1: (b) Assessment of the legality of the Agency's Plan must be guided by the decision in Weber.  An employer seeking to justify the adoption of an affirmative action plan need not point to its own prior discriminatory practices
column2: but need point only to a conspicuous imbalance in traditionally segregated job categories.  Voluntary employer action can play a crucial role in furthering Title VII's purpose of eliminating the effects of discrimination in the workplace
column3: and Title VII should not be read to thwart such efforts.  Pp.  480 U. S. 627-630.

column1: (c) The employment decision here was made pursuant to a plan prompted by concerns similar to those of the employer in Weber
column2: supra.  Consideration of the sex of applicants for skilled craft jobs was justified by the existence of a ""manifest imbalance"" that reflected underrepresentation of women in ""traditionally segregated job categories.""  Id. at 197.  Where a job requires special training
column3: the comparison for determining whether an imbalance exists should be between the employer's workforce and those in the area labor force who possess the relevant qualifications.  If a plan failed to take distinctions in qualifications into account in providing guidance for actual employment decisions
column4: it would improperly dictate mere blind hiring by the numbers.  However
column5: the Agency's Plan did not authorize such blind hiring
column6: but expressly directed that numerous factors be taken into account in making employment decisions
column7: including specifically the number of female applicants qualified for particular jobs.  Thus
column8: despite the fact that no precise short-term goal was yet in place for the Skilled Craft Worker job category when Joyce was promoted
column9: the Agency's management had been clearly instructed that they were not to hire solely by reference to statistics.  The fact that only the long-term goal had been established for the job category posed no danger that personnel decisions would be made by reflexive adherence to a numerical standard.  Pp.  480 U. S. 631-637.

column1: (d) The Agency Plan did not unnecessarily trammel male employees' rights or create an absolute bar to their advancement.  The Plan sets aside no positions for women
column2: and expressly states that its goals should

column1: not be construed as ""quotas"" that must be met.  Denial of the promotion to petitioner unsettled no legitimate
column2: firmly rooted expectation on his part
column3: since the Agency Director was authorized to select any of the seven applicants deemed qualified for the job.  Express assurance that a program is only temporary may be necessary if the program actually sets aside positions according to specific numbers.  However
column4: substantial evidence shows that the Agency has sought to take a moderate
column5: gradual approach to eliminating the imbalance in its workforce
column6: one which establishes realistic guidance for employment decisions
column7: and which visits minimal intrusion on the legitimate expectations of other employees.  Given this fact
column8: as well as the Agency's express commitment to ""attain"" a balanced workforce
column9: there is ample assurance that the Agency does not seek to use its Plan to ""maintain"" a permanent racial and sexual balance.  Pp.  480 U. S. 637-640.

column1: To assist airline employees dislocated as a result of the deregulation of commercial air carriers pursuant to the Airline Deregulation Act of 1978 (Act)
column2: Congress enacted an Employee Protection Program (EPP) as  43 of the Act.  The EPP imposes on covered airlines the ""duty to hire"" dislocated protected employees
column3: who have a ""first right of hire"" in their occupational specialties with any covered airline that is hiring additional employees.  Section 43 authorizes the Secretary of Labor to issue regulations for the administration of the EPP
column4: but  43(f)(3) contains a legislative veto provision stating that any final regulation shall become effective after 60 legislative days following its submission to Congress
column5: unless
column6: during that period
column7: either House of Congress adopts a resolution disapproving it.  Petitioners
column8: airlines subject to the Act's duty-to-hire provisions
column9: filed suit in Federal District Court
column10: which granted summary judgment for them
column11: holding  43(f)(3)'s legislative veto provision unconstitutional under INS v. Chadha
column13: and striking down the entire EPP on the ground that the veto provision was nonseverable.  On appeal from the finding of nonseverability

column1: Held:  Section 43(f)(3)'s legislative veto provision is severable from the remainder of the EPP program.  Pp.  480 U. S. 684-697.
(a) The standard for determining the severability of an unconstitutional provision in a federal statute is that
column2: unless it is evident that Congress would not have enacted those provisions which are within its power independently of that which is not
column3: the invalid part may be dropped if what is left is fully operative as a law.  The relevant inquiry in evaluating severability is whether the statute will function in a manner consistent with Congress' intent.  In considering this question in the context of a legislative veto
column4: it must be recognized that the absence of the veto necessarily alters the balance of powers between the Legislative and Executive Branches of the Federal Government.  Thus
column5: it is not only appropriate to evaluate the importance of the veto in the original legislative bargain
