Section 243(h) of the Immigration and Nationality Act (Act) requires that the Attorney General withhold deportation of an alien who demonstrates that his ""life or freedom would be threatened"" thereby on account of specified factors.  The above-quoted phrase requires a showing that ""it is more likely than not that the alien would be subject to persecution"" in the country to which he would be returned.  In contrast
column2: 208(a) of the Act authorizes the Attorney General
column3: in his discretion
column4: to grant asylum to a ""refugee
column5: who
column6: under  101(a)(42)(A) of the Act
column7: is unable or unwilling to return to his home country because of persecution or ""a well founded fear"" thereof on account of particular factors.  At respondent illegal alien's deportation hearing
column8: the Immigration Judge applied the  243(h) ""more likely than not"" proof standard to her  208(a) asylum claim
column9: holding that she had not established ""a clear probability of persecution
column10: and therefore was not entitled to relief.  The Board of Immigration Appeals (BIA) affirmed
column11: but the Court of Appeals reversed
column12: holding that  208(a)'s ""well founded fear"" standard is more generous than the  243(h) standard in that it only requires asylum applicants to show either past persecution or ""good reason"" to fear future persecution.  Accordingly
column13: the asylum claim was remanded so that BIA could evaluate it under the proper legal standard.

column1: Held:  The  243(h) ""clear probability"" standard of proof does not govern asylum applications under  208(a).  Pp.  480 U. S. 427-449.

(a) The plain meaning of the statutory language indicates a congressional intent that the proof standards under  208(a) and 243(h) should differ.  Section 243(h)'s ""would be threatened"" standard has no subjective component
column2: but
column3: in fact
column4: requires objective evidence that it is more likely than not that the alien will be subject to persecution upon deportation.  In contrast
column5: 208(a)'s reference to ""fear"" makes the asylum eligibility determination turn to some extent on the alien's subjective mental state
column6: and the fact that the fear must be ""well founded"" does not transform the standard into a ""more likely than not"" one.  Moreover
column7: the different emphasis of the two standards is highlighted by the fact that
column8: although Congress simultaneously drafted  208(a)'s new standard and amended  243(h)
column9: it left  243(h)'s old standard intact.  Pp.  480 U. S. 430-432.

column1: (b) The legislative history demonstrates the congressional intent that different standards apply under  208(a) and 243(h).  Pp.  480 U. S. 432-443.
(c) The argument of the Immigration and Naturalization Service (INS) that it is anomalous for  208(a) to have a less stringent eligibility standard than  243(h)
column2: since  208(a) affords greater benefits than  243(h)
column3: fails
column4: because it does not account for the fact that an alien who satisfies the  208(a) standard must still face a discretionary asylum decision by the Attorney General
column5: while an alien satisfying  243(h)'s stricter standard is automatically entitled to withholding of deportation.  Pp.  480 U. S. 443-445.

column1: (d) The INS's argument that substantial deference should be accorded BIA's position that the ""well founded fear"" and ""clear probability"" standards are equivalent is unpersuasive
column2: since the narrow legal question of identicality is a pure question of statutory construction within the traditional purview of the courts
column3: and is not a question of case-by-case interpretation of the type traditionally left to administrative agencies.  Pp.  480 U. S. 445-448.

column1: Section 4 of Pennsylvania's Bituminous Mine Subsidence and Land Conservation Act (Act) prohibits coal mining that causes subsidence damage to preexisting public buildings
column2: dwellings
column3: and cemeteries.  Implementing regulations issued by Pennsylvania's Department of Environmental Resources (DER) require 50% of the coal beneath  4-protected structures to be kept in place to provide surface support
column4: and extend  4's protection to watercourses.  Section 6 of the Act authorizes the DER to revoke a mining permit if the removal of coal causes damage to a  4-protected structure or area and the operator has not within six months repaired the damage
column5: satisfied any claim arising therefrom
column6: or deposited the sum that repairs will reasonably cost as security.  Petitioners
column7: who own or control substantial coal reserves under Act-protected property
column8: filed suit in Federal District Court seeking to enjoin the DER from enforcing the Act and regulations.  The complaint alleged
column9: inter alia
column10: that Pennsylvania recognizes a separate ""support estate"" in addition to the surface and mineral estates in land; that approximately 90% of the coal petitioners will mine was severed from surface estates between 1890 and 1920; that petitioners typically acquired waivers of any damages claims that might result from coal removal; that  4
column12: and  6 violate the Fifth Amendment's Takings Clause; and that  6 violates Article I's Contracts Clause.  Because petitioners had not yet alleged or proved any specific injury caused by the enforcement of  4 and 6 or the regulations
column13: the only question before the District Court was whether the mere enactment of  4 and 6 and the regulations constituted a taking.  The District Court granted DER's motion for summary judgment on this facial challenge.  The Court of Appeals affirmed
column14: holding that Pennsylvania Coal Co. v. Mahon
column16: does not control; that the Act does not effect a taking; and that the impairment of private contracts effectuated by the Act was justified by the public interests protected by the Act.

column1: 1. Petitioners have not satisfied their burden of showing that  4 and 6 and the regulations' 50% rule constitute a taking of private property without compensation in violation of the Fifth and Fourteenth Amendments.  Pennsylvania Coal does not control this case
column2: because the two factors there considered relevant -- the Commonwealth's interest in enacting the law and the extent of the alleged taking -- here support the Act's constitutionality.  Pp.  480 U. S. 481-502.

column1: (a) Unlike the statute considered in Pennsylvania Coal
column2: the Act is intended to serve genuine
column3: substantial
column4: and legitimate public interests in health
column5: the environment
column6: and the fiscal integrity of the area by minimizing damage to surface areas.  None of the indicia of a statute enacted solely for the benefit of private parties identified in Pennsylvania Coal are present here.  Petitioners' argument that  6's remedies are unnecessary to satisfy the Act's public purposes because of the Commonwealth's insurance program that reimburses repair costs is not persuasive
column7: since the public purpose is served by deterring mine operators from causing damage in the first place by making them assume financial responsibility.  Thus
column8: the Commonwealth has merely exercised its police power to prevent activities that are tantamount to public nuisances.  The character of this governmental action leans heavily against finding a taking.  Pp.  480 U. S. 485-493.

column1: (b) The record in this case does not support a finding similar to the one in Pennsylvania Coal that the Act makes it impossible for petitioners to profitably engage in their business
column2: or that there has been undue interference with their investment-backed expectations.  Because this case involves only a facial constitutional challenge
column3: such a finding is necessary to establish a taking.  However
column4: petitioners have never claimed that their mining operations
column5: or even specific mines
column6: have been unprofitable since the Act was passed
column7: nor is there evidence that mining in any specific location affected by the 50% rule has been unprofitable.  In fact
column8: the only relevant evidence is testimony indicating that  4 requires petitioners to leave 27 million tons (less than 2%) of their coal in place.  Petitioners' argument that the Commonwealth has effectively appropriated this coal
column9: since it has no other useful purpose if not mined
column11: because the 27 million tons do not constitute a separate segment of property for taking law purposes.  The record indicates that only 75% of petitioners' underground coal can be profitably mined in any event
column12: and there is no showing that their reasonable ""investment-backed expectations"" have been materially affected by the  4-imposed duty.  Petitioners' argument that the Act constitutes a taking because it entirely destroys the value of their unique support estate also fails.  As a practical matter
column13: the support estate has value only insofar as it is used to exploit another

column2: the support estate is not a separate segment of property for takings law purposes
column3: since it constitutes just one part of the mine operators' bundle of property rights.  Because petitioners retain the right to mine virtually all the coal in their mineral estates
column4: the burden the Act places on the support estate does not constitute a taking.  Moreover
column5: since there is no evidence as to what percentage of petitioners' support estates
column6: either in the aggregate or with respect to any individual estate
column7: has been affected by the Act
column8: their Takings Clause facial challenge fails.  Pp.  480 U. S. 493-502.

column3: of the Constitution by denying petitioners their right to hold surface owners to their contractual waivers of liability for surface damage.  The Contracts Clause has not been read literally to obliterate valid exercises of the States' police power to protect the public health and welfare.  Here
column4: the Commonwealth has a significant and legitimate public interest in preventing subsidence damage to the  4-protected buildings
column5: cemeteries
column6: and watercourses
column7: and has determined that the imposition of liability on coal companies is necessary to protect that interest.  This determination is entitled to deference
column8: because the Commonwealth is not a party to the contracts in question.  Thus
column9: the impairment of petitioners' right to enforce the generations-old damages waivers is amply justified by the public purposes served by the Act.  Pp.  480 U. S. 502-506.

column1: 1. A person afflicted with the contagious disease of tuberculosis may be a ""handicapped individual"" within the meaning of  504.  Pp.  480 U. S. 280-286.

(a) Respondent is a ""handicapped individual"" as defined in  706 (7)(B) and the HHS regulations.  Her hospitalization in 1957 for a disease that affected her respiratory system and that substantially limited ""one or more of [her] major life activities"" establishes that she has a ""record of . . . impairment.""  Pp.  480 U. S. 280-281.

(b) The fact that a person with a record of impairment is also contagious does not remove that person from  504's coverage.  To allow an employer to justify discrimination by distinguishing between a disease's contagious effects on others and its physical effects on a patient would be unfair
column2: would be contrary to  706(7)(B)(iii) and the legislative history
column3: which demonstrate Congress' concern about an impairment's effect on others
column4: and would be inconsistent with  504's basic purpose to ensure that handicapped individuals are not denied jobs because of the prejudice or ignorance of others.  The Act replaces such fearful
column5: reflexive reactions with actions based on reasoned and medically sound judgments as to whether contagious handicapped persons are ""otherwise qualified"" to do the job.  Pp.  480 U. S. 281-286.

column2: in order to determine whether a person handicapped by contagious disease is ""otherwise qualified"" under  504
column3: the district court must conduct an individualized inquiry and make appropriate findings of fact
column4: based on reasonable medical judgments given the state of medical knowledge
column5: about (a) the nature of the risk (e.g.
column6: how the disease is transmitted)
column7: (b) the duration of the risk (how long is the carrier infectious)
column8: (c) the severity of the risk (what is the potential harm to third parties)
column9: and (d) the probabilities the disease will be transmitted and will cause varying degrees of harm.  In making these findings
column10: courts normally should defer to the reasonable medical judgments of public health officials.  Courts must then determine
column12: whether any ""reasonable accommodation"" can be made by the employer under the established standards for that inquiry.  Pp.  480 U. S. 287-288.

column1: 3. Because the District Court did not make appropriate findings
column2: it is impossible for this Court to determine whether respondent is ""otherwise qualified"" for the job of elementary school teacher
column3: and the case is remanded for additional findings of fact.  Pp.  480 U. S. 288-289.

column1: A bullet fired through the floor of respondent's apartment injured a man on the floor below.  Police entered the apartment to search for the shooter
column2: for other victims
column3: and for weapons
column4: and there seized three weapons and discovered a stocking-cap mask.  While there
column5: one of the policemen noticed two sets of expensive stereo components and
column6: suspecting that they were stolen
column7: read and recorded their serial numbers -- moving some of them
column8: including a turntable
column9: to do so -- and phoned in the numbers to headquarters.  Upon learning that the turntable had been taken in an armed robbery
column10: he seized it immediately.  Respondent was subsequently indicted for the robbery
column11: but the state trial court granted his motion to suppress the evidence that had been seized
column12: and the Arizona Court of Appeals affirmed.  Relying upon a statement in Mincey v. Arizona
column14: that a warrantless search must be ""strictly circumscribed by the exigencies which justify its initiation
column15: the Court of Appeals held that the policeman's obtaining the serial numbers violated the Fourth Amendment because it was unrelated to the shooting
column16: the exigent circumstance that justified the initial entry and search.  Both state courts rejected the contention that the policeman's actions were justified under the ""plain view"" doctrine.

column1: 1. The policeman's actions come within the purview of the Fourth Amendment.  The mere recording of the serial numbers did not constitute a ""seizure
column2: since it did not meaningfully interfere with respondent's possessory interest in either the numbers or the stereo equipment.  However
column3: the moving of the equipment was a ""search"" separate and apart from the search that was the lawful objective of entering the apartment.  The fact that the search uncovered nothing of great personal value to respondent is irrelevant.  Pp.  480 U. S. 324-325.

column1: 2. The ""plain view"" doctrine does not render the search ""reasonable"" under the Fourth Amendment.  Pp.  480 U. S. 325-329.

(a) The policeman's action directed to the stereo equipment was not ipso facto unreasonable simply because it was unrelated to the justification for entering the apartment.  That lack of relationship always exists when the ""plain view"" doctrine applies.  In saying that a warrantless search must be ""strictly circumscribed by the exigencies which justify its initiation
column2: Mincey was simply addressing the scope of the primary
and was not overruling the ""plain view"" doctrine by implication.  Pp.  480 U. S. 325-326.
the search was invalid because
column3: as the State concedes
column4: the policeman had only a ""reasonable suspicion"" -- i.e.
column5: less than probable cause to believe -- that the stereo equipment was stolen.  Probable cause is required to invoke the ""plain view"" doctrine as it applies to seizures.  It would be illogical to hold that an object is seizable on lesser grounds
column6: during an unrelated search and seizure
column7: than would have been needed to obtain a warrant for it if it had been known to be on the premises.  Probable cause to believe the equipment was stolen was also necessary to support the search here
column8: whether legal authority to move the equipment could be found only as the inevitable concomitant of the authority to seize it or also as a consequence of some independent power to search objects in plain view.  Pp.  480 U. S. 326-328.

column1: 3. The policeman's action cannot be upheld on the ground that it was not a ""full-blown search
column2: but was only a ""cursory inspection"" that could be justified by reasonable suspicion instead of probable cause.  A truly cursory inspection -- one that involves merely looking at what is already exposed to view
column3: without disturbing it -- is not a ""search"" for Fourth Amendment purposes
column4: and therefore does not even require reasonable suspicion.  This Court is unwilling to create a subcategory of ""cursory"" searches under the Fourth Amendment.  Pp.  480 U. S. 328-329.

column1: Respondent was charged with various sexual offenses against his minor daughter.  The matter was referred to the Children and Youth Services (CYS)
column2: a protective service agency established by Pennsylvania to investigate cases of suspected child mistreatment and neglect.  During pretrial discovery
column3: respondent served CYS with a subpoena
column4: seeking access to the records related to the immediate charges
column5: as well as certain earlier records compiled when CYS investigated a separate report that respondent's children were being abused.  CYS refused to comply with the subpoena
column6: claiming that the records were privileged under a Pennsylvania statute which provides that all CYS records must be kept confidential
column7: subject to specified exceptions.  One of the exceptions is that CYS may disclose reports to a ""court of competent jurisdiction pursuant to a court order.""  At an in-chambers hearing in the trial court
column8: respondent argued that he was entitled to the information because the CYS file might contain the names of favorable witnesses
column9: as well as other unspecified exculpatory evidence.  Although the trial judge did not examine the entire CYS file
column10: he refused to order disclosure.  At the trial
column11: which resulted in respondent's conviction by a jury
column12: the main witness against him was his daughter
column13: who was cross-examined at length by defense counsel.  On appeal
column14: the Pennsylvania Superior Court held that the failure to disclose the daughter's statements contained in the CYS file violated the Confrontation Clause of the Sixth Amendment.  The court vacated the conviction and remanded for further proceedings to determine whether a new trial should be granted.  On the State's appeal
column15: the Pennsylvania Supreme Court held that
column16: by denying access to the CYS file
column17: the trial court order had violated both the Confrontation and the Compulsory Process Clauses of the Sixth Amendment
column18: and that the conviction must be vacated and the case remanded to determine if a new trial was necessary.  The court concluded that defense counsel was entitled to review the entire file for any useful evidence.

column2: and the case is remanded.

column4: reversed in part

column1: 1. This Court does not lack jurisdiction on the ground that the decision below is not a ""final judgment or decree

column5: but in which later review of the federal issue cannot be had whatever the ultimate outcome of the case.  Here

column8: and unless this Court reviews that decision

column1: 2. Criminal defendants have the right under the Compulsory Process Clause to the government's assistance in compelling the attendance of favorable witnesses at trial and the right to put before a jury evidence that might influence the determination of guilt.  However
column2: this Court has never held that the Clause guarantees the right to discover the identity of witnesses
column3: or to require the government to produce exculpatory evidence.  Instead
column4: claims such as respondent's traditionally have been evaluated under the broader protections of the Due Process Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment.  Compulsory process provides no greater protections in this area than those afforded by due process
column5: and thus respondent's claims more properly are considered by reference to due process.  Pp.  480 U. S. 55-56.

column2: the government has the obligation to turn over evidence in its possession that is both favorable to the accused and material to guilt or punishment.  Evidence is material only if there is a reasonable probability that
column3: had the evidence been disclosed
column4: the result of the proceeding would have been different.  Although the public interest in protecting sensitive information such as that in CYS records is strong
column5: this interest does not necessarily prevent disclosure in all circumstances.  Because the Pennsylvania Legislature contemplated some use of CYS records in judicial proceedings
column6: there is no reason to believe that relevant information would not be disclosed when a court of competent jurisdiction determined that the information was ""material"" to the accused's defense. column1: Respondent was charged with various sexual offenses against his minor daughter.  The matter was referred to the Children and Youth Services (CYS)
column2: a protective service agency established by Pennsylvania to investigate cases of suspected child mistreatment and neglect.  During pretrial discovery
column3: respondent served CYS with a subpoena
column4: seeking access to the records related to the immediate charges
column5: as well as certain earlier records compiled when CYS investigated a separate report that respondent's children were being abused.  CYS refused to comply with the subpoena

column7: subject to specified exceptions.  One of the exceptions is that CYS may disclose reports to a ""court of competent jurisdiction pursuant to a court order.""  At an in-chambers hearing in the trial court

column9: as well as other unspecified exculpatory evidence.  Although the trial judge did not examine the entire CYS file

column11: which resulted in respondent's conviction by a jury
column12: the main witness against him was his daughter

column18: and that the conviction must be vacated and the case remanded to determine if a new trial was necessary.  The court concluded that defense counsel was entitled to review the entire file for any useful evidence.

column3: one occupied by McWebb and one by respondent.  Before the officers became aware that they were in respondent's apartment

column1: A provision of the Airport and Airway Improvement Act of 1982
column3: prohibits the imposition of discriminatory state or local property taxes on air carriers.  However
column4: 1513(d)(3) provides that the prohibition does not apply to any ""in lieu tax which is wholly utilized for airport and aeronautical purposes.""  The South Dakota Airline Flight Property Tax
column5: enacted in 1961
column6: is imposed on air carriers on the basis of the value of their aircraft
column7: and provides for allocation of the taxes to the airports used by the carriers
column8: and for use of the taxes exclusively by the airports for airport purposes.  This tax
column9: which is centrally assessed
column10: was an exception from the general state scheme of local property tax assessment at the county level.  In 1978
column11: the State exempted from ad valorem taxation all personal property that was locally
column13: assessed.  Appellant airline companies paid their flight property taxes in 1983 under protest
column14: unsuccessfully sought refunds from appropriate county and state authorities
column15: and ultimately sought relief on appeals to a South Dakota Circuit Court on the ground that
column16: because airline flight property was subject to taxation
column17: while most other personal property was exempt
column18: the state tax violated 1513(d)(1).  The court consolidated the actions and held that the state tax was permitted under  1513(d)(3).  Although disagreeing with that holding
column19: the South Dakota Supreme Court affirmed on an alternative ground based on its interpretation of other provisions of  1513(d).

column1: Held:  The South Dakota tax is an ""in lieu tax which is wholly utilized for airport and aeronautical purposes"" under  1513(d)(3)
column2: and thus does not violate the antidiscrimination provisions of  1513(d).  The question whether a state tax is an ""in lieu tax"" under  1513(d)(3) is one of federal law
column3: and the purpose and effect of the state tax must be examined in light of the policy embodied in the federal law.  Section 1513(d)(3)'s requirement that the state tax be ""wholly utilized for airport and aeronautical purposes"" reflects the federal policy of preventing state and local governments from excessively taxing nonvoting
column4: nonresident businesses in order to subsidize general welfare services for state residents.  The phrase ""in lieu tax"" restricts  1513(d)(3)'s protection to property taxes applied to the exclusion of any other tax on the property -- that is
column5: to

column1: taxes applied in lieu of any other possible property tax -- and reinforces the policy reflected in the ""wholly utilized for airport and aeronautical purposes"" phrase.  The South Dakota Airline Flight Property Tax establishes a method of taxing a particular type of property to the exclusion of any other tax on that property.  It therefore stands in lieu of the generally applicable ad valorem property tax that had been assessed on most other commercial and industrial property in the State at the time the airline flight property tax was established.  It is not necessary that
column2: in order to be exempted under  1513(d)(3)
column3: the state tax must take the place of another tax that historically had been applied to the airline property.  Pp.  480 U. S. 129-134.

column1: A jury found respondent guilty of forcible rape and first-degree murder at his California state court trial.  At the penalty phase
column2: the trial court instructed the jury to consider and weigh the aggravating and mitigating circumstances
column3: but cautioned that the jury ""must not be swayed by mere sentiment
column4: conjecture
column5: sympathy
column6: passion
column7: prejudice
column8: public opinion or public feeling.""  On automatic appeal
column9: the California Supreme Court reversed respondent's death sentence
column10: holding that the quoted instruction violated federal constitutional law by denying respondent the right to have ""sympathy factors"" raised by the evidence considered by the jury when determining the appropriate penalty.

column1: Held:  The instruction in question does not violate the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments when given during the penalty phase of a capital murder trial.  Pp.  479 U. S. 541-543.

(a) The instruction does not violate either of the Eighth Amendment's prerequisites to a valid death sentence that sentencers not be given unbridled discretion and that defendants be allowed to introduce any relevant mitigating evidence.  P.  479 U. S. 541.

(b) The California Supreme Court improperly focused solely on the word ""sympathy"" in the instruction.  A reasonable juror would be unlikely to single out the word ""sympathy"" from the other nouns accompanying it
column2: and would most likely interpret the admonition to avoid basing a decision on ""mere sympathy"" as a directive to ignore only the sort of sympathy that was not rooted in the aggravating and mitigating evidence introduced during the penalty phase.  Pp.  479 U. S. 541-543.

column1: (c) By limiting the jury's sentencing considerations to record evidence
column2: the instruction serves the useful purpose of cautioning the jury against reliance on extraneous emotional factors
column3: and thereby fosters the Eighth Amendment's need for reliability in death sentence determinations and ensures the availability of meaningful judicial review.  P.  479 U. S. 543.
reversed and remanded.

column1: Held:  A suspect's awareness of all the crimes about which he may be questioned is not relevant to determining the validity of his decision to waive the Fifth Amendment privilege; accordingly
column2: the ATF agents' failure to inform respondent of the subject matter of the interrogation could not affect his decision to waive that privilege in a constitutionally significant manner.  Pp.  479 U. S. 571-577.

column1: (a) A confession cannot be ""fruit of the poisonous tree"" if the tree itself is not poisonous.  Pp.  479 U. S. 571-572.

(b) Respondent's March 30 decision to waive his Fifth Amendment privilege was voluntary absent evidence that his will was overborne and his capacity for self-determination critically impaired because of coercive police conduct.  His waiver was also knowingly and intelligently made
column2: that is
column3: he understood that he had the right to remain silent and that anything he said could be used as evidence against him.  The Constitution does not require that a suspect know and understand every possible consequence of a waiver of the Fifth Amendment privilege.  Here
column4: there was no allegation that respondent failed to understand that privilege or that he misunderstood the consequences of speaking freely.   479 U. S.  573-575.

column1: (c) Mere silence by law enforcement officials as to the subject matter of an interrogation is not ""trickery"" sufficient to invalidate a suspect's waiver of Miranda  rights.  Once Miranda warnings are given
column2: it is difficult to see how official silence could cause a suspect to misunderstand the nature of his constitutional privilege to refuse to answer any questions that might incriminate him.  The additional information in question in this case could affect only the wisdom of a Miranda waiver
column3: not its voluntary and knowing nature.  Pp.  479 U. S. 575-577.

column2: an Alabama city that has a long history of racial discrimination and that until recently had an all-white population
column3: is covered by  6 of the Voting Rights Act of 1966 (Act)
column4: and accordingly must seek preclearance before instituting any change in a standard
column5: practice
column6: or procedure affecting voting.  Appellant sought approval by the Attorney General for the annexation of two parcels of land
column7: one vacant (hereinafter called the Western Addition) and the other (Glasgow Addition) added at the request of its inhabitants
column8: an extended white family who wished their children to attend appellant's then all-white school system.  The Attorney General objected to the annexations
column9: finding with respect to the Western Addition that appellant's refusal to annex an adjacent black neighborhood (Highlands) was indicative of an intent to annex only white areas.  Pursuant to  5 of the Act
column10: appellant then filed this declaratory action in the United States District Court for the District of Columbia
column12: finding that the Western Addition's location and appellant's plans for relatively expensive housing there indicated that it was likely to be developed for use by white persons only.  The court further found that appellant failed to carry its burden of proving that the annexations at issue did not have the purpose of abridging or denying the right to vote on account of race.

column2: governing this case

column4: and even the annexation of vacant land on which residential development is anticipated must be precleared before those moving into the area may vote in the annexing jurisdiction.  Moreover
column5: Congress intended that a voting practice not be precleared unless both discriminatory purpose and effect are absent
column6: and the burden of proving absence of discriminatory purpose and effect is on the covered jurisdiction.  Pp.  479 U. S. 467-469.

column3: as appellant asserted
column4: based upon economic considerations.  The court's findings
column5: both as to the purpose of not annexing the Highlands and with respect to the weight of the evidence regarding the purpose of the two annexations at issue

column7: and appellant has not established that they are clearly erroneous.  Appellant's argument that
column8: even if its decision not to annex the Highlands was racially motivated
column9: such decision was not a change respecting voting
column10: and hence was not subject to  5
column12: but not dispositive.  The failure to annex black areas while simultaneously annexing nonblack areas is highly significant in demonstrating that appellant's annexations were purposefully designed to perpetuate it as an enlarged enclave of white voters.  Moreover

column18: but to their future effects as well
column21: an impermissible purpose under  5 may relate to anticipated as well as present circumstances.  Pp.  479 U. S. 469-472.

The Brooke Amendment to the Housing Act of 1937 imposed a ceiling on rents charged to low-income persons living in public housing projects
column2: and
column3: as later amended
column4: provides that a low-income family ""shall pay as rent"" a specified percentage of its income.  The Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) has consistently considered ""rent"" to include a reasonable amount for the use of utilities.  Petitioners
column5: tenants living in low-income housing projects owned by respondent
column6: brought suit in Federal District Court under 42 U.S.C.  1983
column7: alleging that respondent overbilled them for their utilities and thereby violated the rent ceiling imposed by the Brooke Amendment and implementing regulations.  The District Court granted summary judgment for respondent
column8: holding that a private cause of action was unavailable to enforce the Brooke Amendment.  The Court of Appeals affirmed
column9: holding that
column10: while the Brooke Amendment confers rights on tenants
column11: these rights are enforceable only by HUD.

column1: 1. Nothing in the Housing Act or the Brooke Amendment evidences that Congress intended to preclude petitioners'  1983 claim against respondent.  Not only are the Brooke Amendment and its legislative history devoid of any express indication that exclusive enforcement authority was vested in HUD
column2: but also both congressional and agency actions have indicated that enforcement authority is not centralized
column3: and that private actions were anticipated.  Neither are the remedial mechanisms provided by the statute sufficiently comprehensive and effective to raise a clear inference that Congress intended to foreclose a  1983 cause of action for the enforcement of tenants' rights secured by federal law.  Pp.  479 U. S. 423-429.

column1: 2. There is no merit to respondent's argument that the provision for a ""reasonable"" allowance for utilities is too vague and amorphous to confer on tenants an enforceable ""right"" within the meaning of  1983
column2: and that the matter of utility allowances must be left to the public housing authorities
column3: subject to HUD's supervision.  The benefits Congress intended to confer on tenants are sufficiently specific and definite to qualify

column2: and are not beyond the judiciary's competence to enforce.  Pp.  479 U. S. 429-430.

column1: (a) Failure to apply a newly declared constitutional rule to criminal cases pending on direct review violates basic norms of constitutional adjudication.  After this Court has announced a new rule in the case selected for review

column3: the use of a ""clear break"" exception creates the same problem of not treating similarly situated defendants the same. column1: Under  101-bb of New York's Alcoholic Beverage Control Law and implementing regulations of the State Liquor Authority (SLA)
column2: liquor retailers must charge at least 112 percent of the wholesaler's ""posted"" bottle price in effect at the time the retailer sells or offers to sell the item.  Wholesalers must file monthly ""posted"" bottle prices and case prices for an item with the SLA
column3: and may reduce the posted case price for an item without reducing its bottle price.  Since retailers generally purchase liquor by the case
column4: wholesalers thus can compel retailers to charge more than 112 percent of the actual wholesale cost to the retailer.  As a result of appellant retailer's selling certain bottles of liquor for less than 112 percent of the posted bottle price
column5: its license was suspended for 10 days and it forfeited a bond.  Appellant sought relief from the penalties on the ground that  101-bb violated  1 of the Sherman Act.  A New York Supreme Court denied relief
column6: but the Appellate Division reversed.  The New York Court of Appeals upheld the validity of  101-bb and reinstated the penalties.  It held that  101-bb was not immune under the state action exemption from the antitrust laws set forth in Parker v. Brown
column7: 317 U. S. 341.  The Court of Appeals nevertheless concluded that the statute was a proper exercise of powers reserved to the State by the Twenty-first Amendment.

column1: 1. Section 101-bb is inconsistent with  1 of the Sherman Act.  Resale price maintenance has long been regarded as a per se antitrust violation.  The New York statute
column2: which applies to all liquor wholesalers and retailers
column3: allows ""vertical control"" by wholesalers of retail prices.  Such industry-wide resale price-fixing is virtually certain to reduce both interbrand and intrabrand competition
column4: because it prevents wholesalers from allowing or requiring retail price competition.  Cf. California Retail Liquor Dealers Assn. v. Midcal Aluminum
column5: Inc.

column1: 2. New York's pricing system is not valid under the state action exemption from the antitrust laws.  The State's system does meet the first requirement of the two-part test for determining immunity under Parker v. Brown
column2: supra
column3: that the challenged restraint be ""one clearly articulated and affirmatively expressed as state policy.""  However

column1: New York's liquor pricing system does not meet the second requirement that the State's policy be ""actively supervised"" by the State itself.  New York simply authorizes price setting and enforces the prices established by private parties.  The State has displaced competition among liquor retailers without substituting an adequate system of regulation.  Cf. California Retail Liquor Dealers Assn. v. Midcal Aluminum
column2: Inc.

column1: 3. New York's pricing system is not valid under the Twenty-first Amendment.  Although  2 of the Amendment qualifies the federal commerce power
column2: the Amendment does not operate to ""repeal"" the Commerce Clause wherever state regulation of intoxicating liquors is concerned.  The question in each case is whether the interests implicated by a state regulation are so closely related to the powers preserved by the Twenty-first Amendment that the regulation may prevail
column3: notwithstanding that its requirements directly conflict with express federal policies.  Pp.  479 U. S. 346-352.

column1: (a) The State's asserted interest in protecting small retailers does not suffice to afford immunity from the Sherman Act. Although the New York Court of Appeals correctly concluded that the purpose of the 12 percent minimum markup was to protect those retailers
column2: the court made no findings that the purpose of the ""bottle price"" definition of cost was to protect small retailers
column3: and cited no legislative or other findings that either the markup or the ""bottle price"" definition of cost has been effective in preserving the retailers.  The State's resale price maintenance system directly conflicts with the ""familiar and substantial"" federal interest in enforcing the antitrust laws.  Pp.  479 U. S. 348-351.

column1: (b) It is not necessary to consider whether New York's pricing system can be upheld as an exercise of the State's power to promote temperance.  The Court of Appeals did not find that the statute was intended to promote temperance
column2: or that it does so.  This Court accords great weight to the views of the State's highest court on state law matters
column3: and customarily accepts the factual findings of state courts in the absence of exceptional circumstances.  No such exceptional circumstances appear in this case.  Pp.  479 U. S. 351-352.
reversed and remanded.
